author: By Ilana M. Horwitz
title: I Followed the Lives of 3,290 Teenagers. This Is What I Learned About Religion and Education.
description: Boys from working-class families benefit from the social capital that religious belief can provide.
content: American men are dropping out of college in alarming numbers. A slew of articles over the past year depict a generation of men who feel lost, detached and lacking in male role models. This sense of despair is especially acute among working-class men, fewer than one in five of whom completes college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maile Meloy
title: At a School for the Deaf, Signs of Change Are Clear
description: Sara Novic’s new novel, “True Biz,” takes readers beyond the hearing world.
content: TRUE BIZBy Sara Novic
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: A Very Merry Holiday Redo
description: The Omicron surge — both the illness and precautions that came with it — bungled many a holiday gathering. Now, some are making up for it.
content: Like many companies, DADA Goldberg, a real estate and design public relations agency in New York City, canceled its annual holiday dinner after a handful of employees tested positive for Covid-19 during the Omicron surge in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: ‘Minute-to-Minute Triage’: Weighing News Against Safety in Russia
description: Western news outlets are engaging in a tense debate over balancing an urgent need to bear witness with journalists’ ability to report freely under strict new laws there.
content: Shortly after Russia passed a new censorship law that effectively criminalized accurate reporting on the war in Ukraine, CNN executives on two continents gathered for an emergency video call to figure out what would happen next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: On a trip shrouded in secrecy, 3 European leaders travel to Kyiv to offer support.
description: “It is here, in war-torn Kyiv, that history is being made,” one European leader wrote after arriving in Ukraine’s battered capital.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — The leaders of three eastern members of the European Union traveled to Kyiv on Tuesday on a high-risk mission that was kept under wraps until after they had boarded a train to the embattled Ukrainian capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson and Nicholas Calcott
title: A Greenwich Village Renovation That Steered Its Owners’ Line in a New Direction
description: Bessie and Oliver Corral of Arjé started designing home goods at the same time that they were remaking their duplex into a bright and minimalist sanctuary.
content: THE MARRIED DESIGNERS Bessie and Oliver Corral bring both laid-back Mediterranean warmth and unstoppable drive to everything they do. When, in the early months of the pandemic, Oliver, 48, began making sourdough bread for Bessie’s family, with whom they were staying in London, it wasn’t long before he graduated to baguettes and croissants, producing them in such quantities that he briefly considered opening a bakery (instead, he delivered his surplus to friends around the city). That spring, away from their jobs and home in New York, the pair also thought about updating their apartment, a 2,000-square-foot duplex in Greenwich Village. But what began as a plan to simply repaint the walls evolved, when they returned to Manhattan that summer, into an all-encompassing renovation — one they completed entirely themselves. “We both have this obsessive world in our brains,” says Bessie, 35. “It’s a little dangerous.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Oil prices fall below $100 a barrel as China’s Covid-19 outbreak threatens demand.
description: Gas prices in the United States were lower on Tuesday. Stock markets rose, with the gains on Wall Street led by airlines.
content: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday, falling below $100 a barrel, as China, the world’s largest oil importer, imposed new lockdowns to combat an outbreak of the coronavirus, moves that could threaten demand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Olivia Rodrigo, BTS and Billie Eilish to Perform at Grammys
description: The 64th annual awards ceremony, the second in a row to be delayed by the pandemic, will be held in Las Vegas on April 3.
content: Olivia Rodrigo, Billie Eilish, BTS and Lil Nas X will perform at the 64th annual Grammy Awards on April 3, the Recording Academy announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Valerie Hopkins
title: Officials in Mariupol struggle to account for the dead.
description: The coastal city, a battleground for weeks, is under an increasingly relentless Russian assault that is taking an unspeakable toll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: As Virus Data Mounts, the J.&J. Vaccine Holds Its Own
description: Once dismissed as less effective, the vaccine now seems to be preventing infections and illness about as well as the two mRNA options.
content: Roughly 17 million Americans received the Johnson & Johnson Covid vaccine, only to be told later that it was the least protective of the options available in the United States. But new data suggest that the vaccine is now preventing infections, hospitalizations and deaths at least as well as the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Nets Fined $50,000 for Letting Kyrie Irving Into Their Locker Room
description: Irving is not allowed to be with the Nets at Barclays Center because he has not been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
content: The N.B.A. fined the Nets $50,000 for allowing guard Kyrie Irving to enter the team’s locker room during Sunday’s game against the Knicks even though Irving had not been vaccinated against the coronavirus and thus was not allowed to be with the team at Barclays Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Amelia Nierenberg
title: A Groggy Senate Approves Making Daylight Saving Time Permanent
description: Legislation that passed unanimously would end the practice of setting clocks back one hour in the fall. Its prospects were uncertain in the House.
content: WASHINGTON — After losing an hour of sleep over the weekend, members of the United States Senate returned to the Capitol this week a bit groggy and in a mood to put an end to all this frustrating clock-changing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Kleeman
title: Michelle Yeoh’s Quantum Leaps
description: For her new sci-fi comedy, the martial-arts star had to attempt a more psychological kind of acrobatics.
content: In 1995, many years into working as an action star, Michelle Yeoh plummeted from an 18-foot overpass and nearly ended her career. It was her first role in a character-driven drama, playing the lead in “The Stunt Woman,” directed by Ann Hui, a prominent filmmaker of the Hong Kong New Wave. The script called for her to channel nearly a decade of experience as a martial artist into the character of Ah Kam, a stunt woman working her way into the film industry. This scene was crucial: As Ah Kam hesitated over the performance of a daunting on-camera stunt, the character played by Sammo Hung, a legend of kung fu cinema, would push her, and she would fall over the ledge onto the bed of a passing truck. “When it’s an easy stunt,” Yeoh says, “that’s when things can really go wrong.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: The U.K. targets more oligarchs and Putin allies with sanctions.
description: More than 370 people are being penalized, including Russia’s prime minister, a former president and the Kremlin’s press secretary.
content: LONDON — The British government said on Tuesday that it had imposed sanctions on more than 370 individuals it described as oligarchs, political allies or propagandists for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, a major new crackdown that brings it closer in line with the European Union on an issue that has long dogged Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen and Rebecca Robbins
title: In Africa, a Mix of Shots Drives an Uncertain Covid Vaccination Push
description: Supplies are more plentiful now but they are unpredictable and often a jumble of brands. Many places can’t meet the W.H.O.’s recommended dosing schedules.
content: KAMAKWIE, Sierra Leone — In the tumbledown concrete room that has been commandeered as this sleepy African trading center’s Covid-19 vaccination headquarters, a battered freezer holds stacks of boxes with dozens of small glass vials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: A Year After Suez Blockage, Another Evergreen Ship Is Mired in the Chesapeake
description: The Ever Forward ran aground after leaving Baltimore on Sunday, nearly a year after the Ever Given became lodged in the Suez Canal, disrupting global trade for nearly a week.
content: A container ship operated by the same company whose vessel blocked the Suez Canal last year, holding up billions of dollars in global trade for nearly a week, has been stuck in the Chesapeake Bay since Sunday night, according to officials in Maryland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Sever Ties With My Selfish Sister?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to renew a relationship with an estranged sibling.
content: Several years ago, I told my sister that I wouldn’t be upset if we never spoke again. Recently her husband, with whom I have a good relationship, asked me to reconsider. I’m torn. I don’t want to have any contact with her, but I don’t want to deny my two adult daughters contact with the only family that exists on my side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Allison Herren Lee will step down as S.E.C. commissioner, opening another vacancy at the agency.
description: Ms. Lee earned praise from some of her colleagues for her decisive approach on environmental disclosures.
content: Allison Herren Lee will step down as a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Five animated shows based on Dr. Seuss books are headed to Netflix.
description: The streaming service is expanding more aggressively into the preschool space.
content: Building on a partnership started in 2019, Netflix and the Dr. Seuss estate announced Tuesday that they were creating five new animated series and specials for preschoolers based on the work of the famed children’s author.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dean Bakopoulos
title: Is Love Enough to Save a City?
description: Kelsey Ronan’s debut novel, “Chevy in the Hole,” follows a budding romance between opposites amid a civic crisis.
content: CHEVY IN THE HOLEBy Kelsey Ronan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Covid Lockdowns Set to Further Disrupt Global Supply Chains
description: A surge in Omicron variant infections has prompted Chinese authorities to lock down residents, close factories and stop truck traffic, snarling already frayed supply chains.
content: BEIJING — Trucks are being delayed by the testing of drivers. Container rates are rising as ships wait for many hours at ports. Products are piling up in warehouses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsea Leu
title: A Novel-in-Stories of Queerness and Corruption in Lagos
description: Eloghosa Osunde’s “Vagabonds!” is set in the Nigerian capital, where homosexuality is punished by law.
content: VAGABONDS! By Eloghosa Osunde
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Russian Artists Lose the Tools of Their Trades as Companies Pull Out
description: Creative professionals have been cut off from Western clients and from the products and services they use to make, market and get paid for their work.
content: In a call from his car on Sunday, a photographer from Moscow explained why he was driving to Tbilisi, Georgia, having left his apartment and essentially his whole life behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Shalanda Young Confirmed to Head Biden’s Budget Office
description: Ms. Young is the first Black woman to lead the Office of Management and Budget, which had been without permanent leadership for more than a year.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate confirmed Shalanda Young on Tuesday to serve as the director of the Office of Management and Budget, giving the agency permanent leadership for the first time in more than a year as it prepares the second budget of the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: In Impasse Over New Covid Relief Aid, Neither Side Is Willing to Bend
description: The White House wants more money for treatments, tests, vaccines and research, but Republicans in Congress insist the administration will have to repurpose existing funds.
content: WASHINGTON — Prospects looked bleak on Tuesday for congressional approval of billions of dollars in new emergency aid to fight Covid-19, and White House officials said they had already scaled back plans to purchase treatments and reimburse doctors who care for uninsured Covid patients because pandemic relief money has run out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: E.U. Leaders Visit Kyiv
description: Plus the ripple effects of China’s surge of Covid cases and a once-perilous road in Afghanistan.
content: The prime ministers of the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovenia traveled by train to Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Tuesday to express the European Union’s support for Ukraine. Next week, President Biden will travel to Brussels to attend a special NATO meeting about the war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Will Powell Be Forced to Duplicate a Fed Giant?
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 15, 2022.
content: “We have never put our economy into a deep freeze and then defrosted it before.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mooj Zadie, Rachel Quester, Rachelle Bonja, Rikki Novetsky, Paige Cowett, John Ketchum, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Story Behind a Defining War Photo
description: Lynsey Addario, a photojournalist, took an image that captured the new reality of the fighting in Ukraine.
content: This episode details graphic scenes and contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Impunity for War Crimes in Syria Casts a Grim Shadow Over Ukraine
description: Syria, with Russian support, used many of the brutal tactics now seen in Ukraine — and its dictator stayed in power. That conflict offers lessons for Russia’s leader, analysts say.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian police stormed her house and dragged her husband away. Her eldest son died in a rain of Syrian government shells on her hometown. So like millions of other Syrians, Hanadi Hafisi fled the country with plans to return when the war ended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Remains of Child Known as ‘Little Miss Nobody’ Are Identified, Sheriff Says
description: In 1960, a child’s body was found by a hiker in a remote part of Arizona. Using DNA technology, investigators were finally able to identify her as Sharon Lee Gallegos, age 4.
content: In July 1960, a little girl’s body, decomposed and burned, was found by a hiker in a remote part of Arizona. The child wore a checkered blouse and white shorts. Adult-size flip-flops had been cut to fit her small feet. Her nails were painted red. She became known as “Little Miss Nobody,” because no one could figure out who she was or how she had died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Attacks on Kyiv.
content: The war in Ukraine entered an uncertain new phase as Russian forces widened their bombardment of Kyiv and other cities, and the U.S. warned China over its deepening alignment with an isolated Russia. Follow our live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Isla & Co. Opens in Williamsburg, Brooklyn
description: Vietnamese-influenced breakfast fare in Chelsea; Thai grilled skewers in Elmhurst, Queens; and more restaurant news.
content: Until 4 p.m., brunch is the main bill of fare at this new restaurant in the former Du’s Donuts space, in the arcade of the William Vale hotel in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Barry Dry and Tom Rowse, the owners of Parched Hospitality Group, which is behind the Hole in the Wall restaurants, have hired Matt Foley, a former sous-chef at Marea, to be executive chef. He’ll run brunch, as well as dinner, with an eclectic menu that includes a burger, fish and chips, rigatoni alla vodka with spicy shrimp, Thai green curry and half a chicken with roasted spring vegetables. Sticky date pudding and lemon panna cotta are the sweets. The restaurant is a spinoff of Isla in the Hotel Hendricks in Manhattan, which reopens Thursday after a long pandemic hiatus. In addition, locations of Isla & Co. will show up this year in Atlanta, Miami Beach and West Palm Beach. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Making the SAT and ACT Optional Is the Soft Bigotry of Low Expectations
description: Intended or not, it sends a message that some students of color are less capable.
content: It isn’t fashionable these days to recall anything good that came out of the George W. Bush era, but the phrase “the soft bigotry of low expectations” was one. It has never been forgotten, and justly so, because our society is rife with exactly such attitudes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Pritzker Prize Goes to Architect From West Africa
description: Using indigenous materials and local symbols, Francis Kéré makes buildings that serve the community he came from.
content: Growing up in a poor village in Burkina Faso, Francis Kéré didn’t play soccer with the other boys. He helped fix houses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: So Long, Medical Scrubs. Jesse Williams Is Ready to Play Ball.
description: The former “Grey’s Anatomy” star is making his Broadway debut in “Take Me Out.” For that, he said, “I needed to go into a very unknown place.”
content: Jesse Williams will be the first tell you — certainly, he was the first to tell me — that he has no formal theater training and little practice. There’s an Edward Albee play in the hazy past and a one-act opposite Zosia Mamet. That’s pretty much it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Mandy Patinkin Finds Healing in Refugee Work and Praying With His Dog
description: Right when the actor thought he’d done almost everything, Ken Burns offered him the role of Benjamin Franklin, and, just maybe, held off an early retirement.
content: Mandy Patinkin arrived so long ago in his career — winning a Tony Award for “Evita” and an Emmy for “Chicago Hope” and being the object of adoration and imitation as Inigo Montoya in “The Princess Bride” — that he likes to jest he’s getting ready to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig S. Smith
title: ‘No-Code’ Brings the Power of A.I. to the Masses
description: A growing number of new products allow anyone to apply artificial intelligence without having to write a line of computer code. Proponents believe the “no-code” movement will change the world.
content: This article is part of a new series on how artificial intelligence has the potential to solve everyday problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Whole Point of the Constitution Was to Weaken the States
description: There’s a reason Madison was a federalist.
content: As millions of Americans see it, the Constitution was written to protect and extend the powers and prerogatives of the states. It established a “limited” national government and preserved, for state governments, any number of rights and responsibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: ‘In the Margins’ Offers a Path Into Elena Ferrante’s Mind
description: In pieces both philosophical and practical, the pseudonymous author shares her conceptions of writing and reading.
content: A couple of years ago, Elena Ferrante accepted an invitation to deliver three lectures to the public in Bologna, Italy. The request was oceanically broad: Ferrante was asked to speak about anything that might be of interest to a general audience. Anything! Then the pandemic happened, and public life ceased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: This Is How World War III Begins
description: Why Putin is likelier to double down than he is to cut his losses.
content: The usual date given for the start of World War II is Sept. 1, 1939, when Hitler invaded Poland after the signing of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact. But that was just one in a series of events that at the time could have seemed disconnected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: A Chinese video blogger in Odessa challenges Beijing’s version of the war.
description: Wang Jixian has become one of the boldest voices confronting the Chinese state-controlled media’s narrative, drawing hundreds of thousands of viewers.
content: In the southern Ukrainian port city of Odessa, Wang Jixian often starts his days by recording the sirens howling warnings to residents against Russian air attacks. It’s part of his own battle against the skewed, euphemistic depiction of the war propagated by Moscow’s crucial partner, China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger and Glenn Thrush
title: Biden will travel to Europe next week for an extraordinary NATO meeting.
description: The president will travel to Brussels for the NATO session, and will also attend a European Union summit meeting.
content: President Biden will travel to an extraordinary NATO summit meeting in Brussels on March 24 and will also attend the European Union’s summit meeting the same day, White House and European officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Maureen Howard, 91, Novelist Who Traced Women’s Challenges, Dies
description: In well-reviewed works like “Natural History” and “A Lover’s Almanac,” she was intent, a fellow writer said, on “making the novel do and hold more.”
content: Maureen Howard, who first drew wide attention in 1965 with her novel “Bridgeport Bus,” which came to be regarded as a precursor to second-wave feminism, and went on to write ambitious, well-regarded books for 45 more years, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Arrive With Good Spirits
description: Michael Lieberman’s puzzle is a peach.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Today’s constructor, Michael Lieberman, made his New York Times Crossword debut just over a year ago, and in that time he has already published six crossword puzzles and four variety puzzles. That’s a pretty impressive record!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, André Spigariol, Jack Nicas and Adam Goldman
title: Submarine Spy Couple Tried to Sell Nuclear Secrets to Brazil
description: Jonathan and Diana Toebbe pleaded guilty last month in the espionage case, but until now the identity of the nation they had approached had remained publicly undisclosed.
content: WASHINGTON — In 2020, a United States naval engineer and his wife made the fateful decision to try to sell some of America’s most closely guarded military secrets, the technology behind the nuclear reactors that power the U.S. submarine fleet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: adversary
description: This word has appeared in 244 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Pfizer and BioNTech Seek Authorization of a Second Booster Shot for Older Americans
description: The move could further inflame a tortuous debate among scientists over when the coronavirus vaccines’ protection should be bolstered, and for whom.
content: WASHINGTON — Pfizer and BioNTech said on Tuesday that they had sought emergency authorization for a second booster shot of their coronavirus vaccine for adults 65 and older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: How Do You React When Your Friendships Change?
description: Have you ever felt left out? Left others out? How have you handled jealousy in your friendships?
content: Have you ever heard the saying that friends come into our lives for a reason, a season or a lifetime? Some friendships last, while others run their course. Do you have friendships now that you hope will last a lifetime? Are any of your current friends people you have known since you were very young? Have you ever become less close to a good friend over time?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Spot Asteroids
description: Be patient. Keep your mortal fear in check.
content: “Stay up all night,” says Gregory Leonard, a research scientist at the University of Arizona’s Catalina Sky Survey, who uses a network of powerful telescopes to find and track what NASA calls near-Earth objects, including asteroids that come within 120 million miles of the sun. An amateur hunter can use the same strategies as a professional. Go looking in a place without light pollution on a cloudless night with a steady atmosphere (if you see stars sparkling, it’s a sign of atmospheric turbulence). Avoid a full moon. Leonard and his asteroid-hunter colleagues tend to be solitary types who don’t mind working solo night shifts and sleeping during the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: How California Is Building the Nation’s First Privacy Police
description: A new state agency has a $10 million budget to regulate Google, Facebook and others. But first it needs to be created.
content: Ashkan Soltani, the head of California’s new online privacy regulator, needed help launching the first agency of its kind in the United States. So he called the state’s Horse Racing Board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark and Adam Satariano
title: Intel to Invest at Least $19 Billion for New Chips Plant in Germany
description: The Silicon Valley company said it would build factories in Magdeburg, mirroring a plan announced in late January to begin manufacturing in Ohio.
content: Intel selected the German city of Magdeburg on Tuesday for its next big chip manufacturing site, continuing a significant expansion aimed at reducing dependence on Asian factories for the vital components.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: 106 Years, 4 Weeks, 1 Wreck: How Shackleton’s Ship Was Found
description: “Gents, I want to introduce you to the Endurance.” More than a century after sinking in Antarctic waters, the legendary ship was found with just days to spare.
content: When perhaps the most celebrated shipwreck in Mensun Bound’s long career as a marine archaeologist was discovered, he was off viewing some penguins a mile away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Ben and Justin Smith Name Gina Chua as Executive Editor at News Start-Up
description: Ms. Chua has been the executive editor of Reuters and in charge of its editorial operations.
content: Gina Chua, a top editor at Reuters, will become the executive editor of a new media start-up helmed by Ben Smith and Justin Smith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: DeSantis vs. Miami’s Archbishop, With Cuban Americans in the Middle
description: Beneficiaries of a program that resettled young Cubans decades ago were outraged after the Miami archbishop compared them to today’s unaccompanied minors.
content: MIAMI — The state was threatening the Roman Catholic Church’s ability to shelter immigrant children when Archbishop Thomas G. Wenski of Miami went for South Florida’s emotional jugular: He compared the unaccompanied children who were crossing the border today to those who fled Communist Cuba six decades ago without their parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: Behind the Entenmann’s Cellophane, a Slice of Long Island Life
description: The passing of a founding baker reminds our writer of what the brand meant, and still does, in its birthplace — banana crunch, polysorbate 60 and all.
content: The tasty crumb of a detail appeared in news accounts last week about the death of Charles E. Entenmann, whose very surname conjures a white-and-blue box with a cellophane glimpse of some baked treat that is both good and bad for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Timothy Snyder on the Myths That Blinded the West to Putin’s Plans
description: The renowned historian on Putin’s myths, Ukrainian identity and the West’s “politics of inevitability.”
content: “Americans and Europeans were guided through the new century by a tale about ‘the end of history,’ by what I will call the politics of inevitability, a sense that the future is just more of the present, that the laws of progress are known, that there are no alternatives, and therefore nothing really to be done,” writes the Yale historian Timothy Snyder in his 2018 book, “The Road to Unfreedom.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Shulman
title: Two Women Related by Blood, Strained by Money, Split by Hardship
description: Elena Medel’s debut novel, “The Wonders,” explores daily life in Spain beyond the tourist clichés.
content: THE WONDERSBy Elena MedelTranslated by Lizzie Davis and Thomas Bunstead
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Hsiung Wojcik
title: My Journey to Making a Crossword Puzzle That Looks Like Me
description: How the Expanded Crossword Name Database helps decolonize the puzzle.
content: Crossword puzzles have an inclusivity problem. In the past decade, people in the puzzle community have called attention to the fact that crossword constructors are more likely to be male than female, and more white than people of color. Clues in these puzzles tend to reference a narrow band of cultural knowledge and experiences that speak to a certain type of solver who knows a lot about the history of baseball and Italian food and nothing about popular music from the 2000s or Sichuan cuisine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Russian Mogul Is Charged With Donating Illegally to U.S. Campaigns
description: Andrey Muraviev was indicted on charges of making donations as a foreign national to boost licensing decisions for a marijuana business.
content: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan on Monday accused a Russian tycoon of scheming to make $1 million in illegal campaign donations to federal and state political candidates in the United States to gain favorable licensing decisions for a cannabis business venture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek
title: Global Economy Sinks Deeper Into Turmoil as Fed Prepares to Raise Rates
description: Federal Reserve officials are set to raise interest rates to control inflation, but the return to normal they had hoped to see remains painfully elusive.
content: WASHINGTON — When Federal Reserve officials raise interest rates on Wednesday, they will do so amid an unfortunate economic reality: Many of the inflationary pressures they had long assumed would dissipate have instead lingered, and some are getting worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Going Back to the Time of the Shakers at Commerce Inn
description: At their latest West Village restaurant, Jody Williams and Rita Sodi revive American farmhouse cooking from an earlier era.
content: An entrepreneur starting an Eritrean or Tibetan or Surinamese restaurant in New York can, by settling in the right neighborhood, count on a built-in audience of people who grew up on the food and presumably will give it at least one whirl. Not so for anyone setting up a Shaker-inspired restaurant, as Jody Williams and Rita Sodi have done on Commerce Street in the West Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The U.S. has made big promises. Where’s the money?
description: The latest spending bill in Congress contains far less money to help developing countries than President Biden had pledged. That fits a pattern.
content: It’s easy making climate promises. It’s harder keeping them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: We Were Worried About Inflation. Then Russia Invaded Ukraine.
description: The Federal Reserve has to juggle conflicting goals of taming inflation and sustaining growth.
content: While the extraordinarily strict sanctions imposed on Russia constitute an admirable policy response to its appalling invasion of Ukraine, we should not be complacent about the potential boomerang effect on the global economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: The war in Ukraine is raising fears of a recession in Germany.
description: Uncertainty looms for German business leaders, who worry that the war could upend their country’s globalized, export-focused economy.
content: Business leaders in Germany are increasingly worried about the impact Russia’s war in Ukraine will have on the German economy, Europe’s largest, where inflation, disrupted supply chains and the high price of energy are leading to fears of a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Katz
title: How to Toilet-Train Your Cat
description: Tired of an overflowing litter box? Charles Mingus has a pamphlet for that.
content: Sometimes, at Charles Mingus’s apartment, you would have to wait outside the bathroom as a cat finished using the toilet. The legendary jazz composer and bassist had grown tired of coming home to an overflowing litter box. So he devised a solution. And in 1954, he wrote it up on a single sheet of paper and began handing out copies. A pamphlet version followed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I’m Not Scared of Anything’: Death and Defiance in a Besieged Ukrainian City
description: The port city of Mykolaiv is being shelled by Russian forces every day. Bodies are piled at the morgue. But residents refuse to succumb.
content: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — Alla Ryabko stood in the courtyard of the city morgue, trembling with grief and rage. Her son, Capt. Roman Ryabko, had been killed in fighting on the first day of the war in Ukraine, but two weeks had passed and his body had not yet been prepared for burial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben H. Winters
title: In ‘Drowning Practice,’ a Dreamlike Vision of the End of the World
description: In Mike Meginnis’s new novel, everybody on earth has the same dream that the world will end soon.
content: DROWNING PRACTICEBy Mike Meginnis
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Indian Court Upholds Ban on Hijabs in Schools
description: One school’s initial ban set off unrest and violence that spread to other schools in the southern state of Karnataka.
content: A top court in the southern Indian state of Karnataka on Tuesday upheld a government order banning Muslim girls from wearing head scarves inside schools, a ruling that is likely to heighten tensions at a time when India is increasingly polarized along religious lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Ukraine War Shifts the Agenda in Congress, Empowering the Center
description: With a crisis rocking Europe, the left is shelving demands for defense cuts and a swift end to fossil fuels, while on the right, Trump-era foreign policy and criticism of Ukraine are fading.
content: WASHINGTON — The escalating crisis in Ukraine is upending policy and political thinking on both the left and the right on Capitol Hill, as an immediate threat to the global order and soaring energy prices empower the political center at the expense of the two parties’ flanks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Talks Tom Brady’s Un-Retirement
description: Noah joked that Brady’s leaving the N.F.L. was like Charlie Sheen’s leaving “Two and a Half Men”: “Yeah, there were still two and a half men but which men? Not men we cared about.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg and Charlie Savage
title: Sept. 11 Prosecutors Are in Plea Talks That Could Avert a Death-Penalty Trial
description: Pentagon prosecutors have struggled for more than a decade to hold the trial of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and his accused accomplices in the attacks.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Prosecutors have opened talks with lawyers for Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the accused mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, and his four co-defendants to negotiate a potential plea agreement that would drop the possibility of execution, according to people with knowledge of the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Last Mountain’ Review: Impossible Summits
description: This documentary from Chris Terrill struggles to make emotional sense of its story, involving a mother and a son who both died on climbs.
content: Even viewers accustomed to mountain-climbing documentaries, in which climbers routinely concede a willingness to face death, may struggle to adjust to the grim stakes of “The Last Mountain,” a documentary that involves two fatal climbs in one family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carribean Fragoza
title: Wildfires, Secrets and Struggles in a Hidden California
description: In her new novel, “Mecca,” Susan Straight creates a wide and deep view of a dynamic, multiethnic Southern California.
content: MECCABy Susan Straight
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Ukraine’s National Anthem Reverberates Around the World
description: “Ukraine’s glory hasn’t perished,” begins the anthem, which is being played by orchestras worldwide as a sign of solidarity with Ukraine.
content: Since Russia invaded Ukraine, the soaring melody of Ukraine’s national anthem has been heard worldwide, from antiwar protests in Moscow to the stages of major concert halls, from N.B.A. basketball arenas to TikTok posts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Health Agency Under Cuomo ‘Misled the Public’ on Nursing Home Deaths
description: The New York State Health Department presented nursing home data that concealed the deaths of 4,100 people, according to an audit by the state comptroller.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — The administration of former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo failed to publicly account for the deaths of about 4,100 nursing home residents in New York during the pandemic, according to an audit released on Tuesday by the state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Doug Emhoff, Vice President’s Husband, Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
description: Vice President Kamala Harris tested negative for the virus on Tuesday, an aide said, but Mr. Emhoff’s positive test forced her to back out of an event with President Biden.
content: WASHINGTON — Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris, tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday, according to a statement from the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Songs That Get Us Through It’
description: In this lesson, students will explore The New York Times Magazine’s annual music issue and create a multimedia piece that comments on the state of music today.
content: Note to teachers: Some of the essays in this collection deal with adult themes. Please preview them and choose those that you think are most appropriate for your students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How to Support a Child on the Gender Spectrum
description: As Texas’ governor attempts to criminalize medical treatments for transgender youth, experts say there are many ways to help adolescents who are questioning their gender.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas declared last month that medical treatments given to transgender adolescents, including puberty-suppressing drugs and hormones, could be considered child abuse under state law. Opponents of the move swiftly responded, including President Biden, who described the decision as “cynical and dangerous.” Investigations of alleged abuse sparked by the order were temporarily halted last week after a state court ruled that the policy was “unconstitutional.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: Cannibalistic Toads Reveal ‘Evolution in Fast Motion,’ Study Finds
description: The toxin that makes cane toads so poisonous is causing them to eat their young, but only in Australia, where they became an out-of-control pest.
content: In Australia, poisonous cane toads have become their own worst enemies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Monika Pronczuk and Victoria Kim
title: Here are the latest developments in Ukraine.
description: KYIV, Ukraine — Three European leaders were traveling to Kyiv on Tuesday to express the European Union’s “unequivocal support” for Ukraine and offer financial help, the Czech and Polish governments said, even as fighting rages around the city, with half a dozen loud blasts shaking central Kyiv in the pre-dawn hours. The leaders of the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovenia were traveling by train and crossed into Ukraine on Tuesday morning, officials said.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Three European leaders were traveling to Kyiv on Tuesday to express the European Union’s “unequivocal support” for Ukraine and offer financial help, the Czech and Polish governments said, even as fighting rages around the city, with half a dozen loud blasts shaking central Kyiv in the pre-dawn hours. The leaders of the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovenia were traveling by train and crossed into Ukraine on Tuesday morning, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The latest: Amazon’s bid for MGM is approved by European regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Kaiser-Schatzlein
title: How Life as a Trucker Devolved Into a Dystopian Nightmare
description: Trucking used to offer good pay, decent benefits and normal hours. What happened?
content: A few years ago, Jon Knope was standing in a rainy parking lot littered with smashed soda bottles in Cartersville, Ga., learning the finer details of how to park a Class 8 combination tractor-trailer. He was in his early 20s, somewhat rootless, and needed a job that would beat hustling on ride share apps in his mother’s station wagon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Gunman in Yoga Studio Killings Raised Red Flags That Were Missed, U.S. Says
description: Scott P. Beierle had a history of “misogynistic extremism” before shooting six women in Tallahassee, Fla., in 2018, killing two, according to a Secret Service analysis.
content: A yearslong trail of red flags signaling a Florida man’s escalating hatred toward women was missed by the authorities before a 2018 shooting at a Florida yoga studio that left two dead and five injured, the U.S. Secret Service found in a new report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Client Charged in Fatal Stabbing of Lawyer, a Tiananmen Activist
description: Jim Li had fought for democracy in China and often worked pro bono. He died in his Queens office after an irate client stabbed him, the police said.
content: A Queens lawyer held a meeting with a young client last week that ended in chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Scenes from the Resistance
description: Mykolaiv is under daily attack but its residents refuse to succumb.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Farrell and David Fernández
title: In This Edwardian Townhouse, the Bathrooms Set the Tone
description: When renovating their London home, a creative couple sacrificed their guest bedroom for the love of a good soak.
content: The moment Charlotte and Angus Buchanan, both 36, acquired their semidetached Edwardian townhouse in the Harlesden area of northwest London in early 2020, they began sketching their fantasy bathrooms. It would be the first time the couple had enough space to create sanctuaries dedicated to their love of long evening soaks (a passion they wanted to instill in their children, Riva, 5, and Wylder, 3). And so, rather than an architectural afterthought, as these hard-working spaces so often are, the two bathrooms became an expression of the family’s vision for life in their new home — and of the distinctly British, often fantastical aesthetic of Buchanan Studio, the creative direction and interior design company the couple founded in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Zelensky calls on Russian troops to surrender.
description: The Ukrainian leader and the Pentagon have both said some Russian soldiers have surrendered or been captured.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called on Russian troops to surrender in a video address posted online early Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Search for a Gunman Who Is Shooting Homeless People
description: The man has shot at least five homeless men in New York City and Washington, officials said.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at the search for the gunman who the authorities say targeted homeless people as they slept on the streets in New York and Washington. We’ll also put questions to Dr. Dave Chokshi, who stepped down as the city’s health commissioner yesterday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Etelka Lehoczky
title: A 50-Year-Old Graphic Biography of Che Guevara That Still Feels Fresh
description: First published in Argentina in 1969, Héctor Germán Oesterheld’s “Life of Che” has finally been translated into English.
content: Ernesto “Che” Guevara may be a timeless revolutionary icon, but that doesn’t mean his biography is necessarily a story for our time. If Héctor Germán Oesterheld weren’t a remarkable writer, it probably wouldn’t be. Revolution was an inherently Marxist concept for Guevara, who gave up his key role in building Fidel Castro’s new Cuba to fight for global communism, guerrilla-style. His outlook doesn’t translate very well to a world that’s watching Ukraine — a republic that won independence when the Soviet Union fell — attempt to defend itself from an authoritarian Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Troy Closson and Ashley Wong
title: Suspect in New York MoMA Stabbing Is Arrested in Philadelphia
description: The New York police had released video that they said showed the suspect, Gary Cabana, attacking workers at the Museum of Modern Art on Saturday.
content: A suspect in the stabbing of two employees at the Museum of Modern Art in New York over the weekend was arrested early Tuesday in Philadelphia, the New York Police Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Republican in Ohio Senate Primary Spoke Offensively About Asians
description: Mike Gibbons, a leading contender to succeed Senator Rob Portman, made the comments in a 2013 podcast on doing business in China.
content: The leading Republican candidate in the Ohio Senate primary employed offensive stereotypes about Asian people in a 2013 podcast, citing a widely discredited book, “The Bell Curve,” that has drawn allegations of racism and sloppy research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Scott Hall, Wrestler Who Rose to Fame as Razor Ramon, Dies at 63
description: Called a “hugely influential superstar” by World Wrestling Entertainment, he was also a founding member of the villainous New World Order with Kevin Nash and Hulk Hogan.
content: Scott Hall, the former professional wrestler who shot to fame in the early 1990s as the arrogant “bad guy” Razor Ramon, known for wearing gold chains and flicking a toothpick at opponents, has died. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Can Germany Break Up With Russian Gas?
description: When a small import threatens to become a big problem.
content: Germany is one of the world’s great trading nations. In 2019, it imported $1.2 trillion worth of goods from all over the world. Only about 2 percent of that total came from Russia. In fact, the Russian Federation, with roughly 144 million people, was only slightly more important in German trade than Ireland, with around five million people. Ordinarily, then, you wouldn’t expect a disruption of economic relations with Russia to have a big effect on the German economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘It’s Hard to Tell Family About Sex, Love or Money’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: My 3-year-old bellows from his crib: “I want to hug ma-ah-ah-mom!” It’s 5 a.m., so I let his plea grow to full throttle before I give him a hug and set him on the ground. I resign myself to being awake; he asks me why the sun is off. “It’s early,” I say. “It’s winter.” My sigh is the sound of the season taking its toll, the signal of my own light dimming. “Turn it on, Mom!” he says. To him, I’m nothing less than an Olympian goddess, a mythic being, whose powers extend all the way to the sun. — Ashley Lefrak
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 15, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 15, 2022.
content: An article on Sunday about Democrats urging President Biden to sharpen campaign messaging ahead of midterm elections misstated the cost of the American Rescue Plan. It is $1.9 trillion, not $1.9 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Josep’ Review: Escaping a Civil War
description: The French cartoonist known as Aurel animates the life of the Catalan illustrator Josep Bartolí, who lived in French internment camps and loved Frida Kahlo.
content: After Barcelona, Spain, fell to Gen. Francisco Franco’s forces in 1939, nearly half a million Spaniards fled to France in what is known as “La Retirada,” or the retreat. The Catalan illustrator and trade unionist Josep Bartolí was one of those who left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Spring Fashion
description: Early 2000s fashion is making a comeback, according to a recent Times article. What will you be wearing this spring?
content: A recent T Magazine article proclaims that “the bare bellies and garish hues of the early 2000s” are back. Why? Well, according to the British designer Christian Cowan, whose spring 2022 collection featured baby blue sequined bandanna tops and plumed headpieces in neon pink, “It’s pretty simple. We want to feel hot, even full of ourselves. It’s the kind of energy we need, especially after two years of boredom.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Daniil Medvedev Loses a Match and No. 1 Ranking, but Faces Bigger Concerns
description: At Indian Wells, the Russian fell in the third round to Gael Monfils of France, as Medvedev faced criticism that Russian players should not be competing because of Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Daniil Medvedev’s reign as the No. 1 men’s tennis player will not last long — at least, not this time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: The T.S.A. has issued hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines for mask mandate violations.
description: Over the past six months, the Transportation Security Administration ramped up civil citations to passengers, mostly aboard airplanes, who refused to comply with mask mandates, slapping them with more than $640,000 in proposed fines, according to a government report released on Monday.
content: Over the past six months, the Transportation Security Administration ramped up civil citations to passengers, mostly aboard airplanes, who refused to comply with mask mandates, slapping them with more than $640,000 in proposed fines, according to a government report released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Prepare for Interest Rate Liftoff
description: How high will the Fed go?
content: For much of recent history, a rise in bond yields signaled that a stronger economy was ahead. Yesterday, the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note jumped to 2.14 percent, the highest it has been since 2019, and about four times higher than its pandemic low point in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Dozens of BuzzFeed Employees Claim They Were Illegally Shortchanged in I.P.O.
description: The group is asking for compensatory damages estimated at more than $8.7 million.
content: Nearly 80 former and current employees of BuzzFeed accused the company in complaints on Tuesday of bungling its stock market debut and denying the workers the chance to sell their shares at a higher price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: A Fox News crew in Ukraine was caught in fighting, leaving two journalists dead.
description: Pierre Zakrzewski, a Fox News cameraman, and Oleksandra Kuvshynova, a Ukrainian journalist, were killed outside Kyiv. A Fox News correspondent, Benjamin Hall, remained hospitalized.
content: A Fox News cameraman and a Ukrainian journalist traveling with him were killed on Monday in Ukraine when their vehicle came under fire outside Kyiv, according to the network and Ukrainian authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Inside the High-Stakes Race to Test the Covid Tests
description: Researchers in Atlanta have helped the federal government evaluate dozens of Covid tests and pioneer a new model for developing novel diagnostics.
content: ATLANTA — When the pandemic hit two years ago, the United States faced an acute shortage of reliable Covid-19 tests. It was the nation’s first major pandemic failure, blinding health experts and the public to the spread of the coronavirus and allowing the pathogen to spread across the country unchecked. And for much of 2020, getting tested required waiting hours just to be swabbed and a week or longer for results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: With Anthems and Flags, the Met Opera Plays for Ukraine
description: A concert to benefit relief efforts featured a young Ukrainian singer, Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy” and the Met’s prima donna of the moment.
content: Vladyslav Buialskyi stood center stage at the Metropolitan Opera, his hand on his heart, and sang the national anthem of his country, Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Ashley Southall and Campbell Robertson
title: Suspect in Shootings of 5 Homeless Men Arrested in Washington
description: The suspect, Gerald Brevard III, has a history of arrests, mental illness and homelessness and was caught after the police in New York received a tip.
content: A 30-year-old Washington man with a history of mental illness and assault charges was arrested early Tuesday in connection with a series of shootings that killed two homeless men in New York and Washington and wounded three others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: India says it’s in talks with Russia about increasing oil imports.
description: The move comes as New Delhi is striving to preserve its relationship with Moscow, its biggest supplier of weapons, at a time when India faces an aggressive China.
content: India is in talks with Moscow about increasing oil imports from Russia in an effort to keep spiraling prices in check, India’s petroleum minister told Parliament this week. The move comes as New Delhi is also striving to preserve its relationship with Moscow, its biggest supplier of weapons, at a time when India faces an aggressive China on its borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Coal prices rise to record levels on Russia supply fears.
description: Coal buyers are trying to lock up supplies amid fears that Russia could respond to sanctions by cutting off exports, an analyst said.
content: Prices for coal used to generate electric power have hit record levels in recent days on fears that supplies from Russia could be disrupted. Prices for thermal or hard coal recently topped $462 a metric ton before easing back to about $380, said Steve Hulton, vice president of coal at Rystad Energy, a consulting firm. He said these were record prices, well above established norms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Her Video Spurred Changes in Women’s Basketball. Did They Go Far Enough?
description: Sedona Prince’s viral TikTok from the 2021 N.C.A.A. women’s tournament led to a gender equity review in college basketball and to changes in the women’s event.
content: There is no counting how many thank-you notes Sedona Prince might receive this month: from the four additional teams that will participate in the now 68-team women’s basketball tournament; from the participating players, whose gift bags will now be identical to those received by their male counterparts; from the new employees the N.C.A.A. hired to beef up its women’s tournament staff; and from the tournament referees, who will now be paid the same as the officials who call the men’s game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoey Poll and Lucia Buricelli
title: The People Who Draw Rocks
description: The Alps’ glaciers are melting, and these Swiss cartographers have work to do.
content: Every few years, Switzerland’s national mapping agency dispatches one of its planes to scour every centimeter of the Swiss Alps, the pilot looping back and forth to capture photographs of changes in the landscape. For the most part, the modifications made to the country’s official map are minor and largely automated: a house pops up here, a funicular there. But lately, for a rarefied group of the agency’s nearly three dozen cartographers, the need for revisions has intensified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Sisson
title: The Next Level in Sustainability: Nature Restoration
description: Developers are no longer aiming to simply preserve nature, but are actively restoring it as a selling point for their projects.
content: When the online travel giant Expedia Group unveiled its $900 million Seattle headquarters in 2019, the 40-acre waterfront campus showcased numerous amenities: a bike path, a soccer field and a beach strewn with driftwood logs for sitting amid the sounds of surf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: A Russian TV worker who protested the war on a live broadcast is fined.
description: In a video following her sentence, the state TV worker said she had been interrogated for 14 hours and “spent two days without sleep.” She still faces a lengthy prison sentence.
content: A Russian state television employee who stormed a live broadcast on Monday was interrogated by the police for 14 hours and fined by a Moscow court on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Nancy Wartik
title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: European Leaders Brave Russian Bombardment in Visit to Kyiv
description: The prime ministers of Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia made the trip as a show of solidarity, but it also bared divisions with other European Union members.
content: LONDON — Three European leaders staged a defiant show of support for Ukraine on Tuesday, traveling to its besieged capital, Kyiv, even as a relentless Russian artillery bombardment left apartment towers in the city ablaze, forcing terrified residents to flee into the street with only the clothes on their backs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airline Ticket Sales Exceed a 2019 Milestone for the First Time
description: February bookings for U.S. travel beat those preceding the pandemic, a data analysis found. Summer looks promising for the industry, if fuel costs cooperate.
content: Rising fuel prices may present an obstacle, but the airline recovery in the United States appears to be on track for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: Fake Heiress Anna Sorokin, Who Swindled Elite, Faces Deportation to Germany
description: Ms. Sorokin, whose fictionalized story was the subject of the TV show “Inventing Anna,” had been detained by immigration authorities on charges of overstaying her visa.
content: Even as her deportation loomed, Anna Sorokin appeared not to believe media speculation that she would soon be sent back to Germany. The rumors were devastating to the fake German heiress, who prefers to be called Anna Delvey and whose exploits were fictionalized on “Inventing Anna,” a Netflix series created by Shonda Rhimes released last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Russia Deploys a Mystery Munition in Ukraine
description: Iskander-M short-range ballistic missiles are releasing a previously unknown decoy designed to evade air-defense systems, an American official said.
content: American intelligence officials have discovered that the barrage of ballistic missiles Russia has fired into Ukraine contain a surprise: decoys that trick air-defense radars and fool heat-seeking missiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California Lawmakers Have Solved Berkeley’s Problem. Is CEQA Next?
description: A legislative fix helps the university avoid an enrollment freeze, but calls persist for an overhaul of a decades-old environmental law.
content: California lawmakers on Monday headed off an enrollment freeze at the University of California, Berkeley, that threatened the growth not only of the iconic campus but also of public education institutions across the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Turkmenistan Leader’s Son Wins Presidential Race
description: The oil-rich country’s dealings are largely opaque, but its central election commission said Serdar Berdymukhammedov had captured nearly 73 percent of the vote.
content: ASHGABAT, Turkmenistan — Turkmenistan established a political dynasty Tuesday, as the authorities said the son of the Central Asian country’s leader won its presidential election after an unusual vote-counting delay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colum McCann
title: His Life Was Too Boring for a Memoir. So He Wrote Ireland’s.
description: In “We Don’t Know Ourselves,” Fintan O’Toole reckons with a life spent in a wildly changing homeland.
content: WE DON’T KNOW OURSELVESA Personal History of Modern IrelandBy Fintan O’Toole
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Doyle
title: Peter Handke’s Tale of the Telling of the Tale
description: In his novel “The Fruit Thief,” the Austrian Nobel laureate tells us not just the story but the conditions from which it emerged.
content: THE FRUIT THIEFOr, One-Way Journey Into the InteriorBy Peter HandkeTranslated by Krishna Winston
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Where Jerry Zaks Goes to Escape the ‘Pure Pleasure’ of the Theater
description: The director of ‘The Music Man’ pays more attention to the furnishings onstage than to those at home. But that suits him fine.
content: Jerry Zaks has never been much for turning an apartment into a home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Big Sky Is Sprawling, Luxurious and Pricey. And, Maybe, the Future of Skiing.
description: With lift tickets above $225 and surcharges of up to $100 to ride the tram to the top, the vast Montana resort is delivering a high-end experience. Is it a solution to skiing’s problems?
content: The dominant landmark at the Big Sky ski resort in Montana is Lone Peak. At 11,166 feet, it towers majestically over the entire area. It is also a little daunting: From the top, which is reached by a 15-passenger tram, you can bask in stunning 360-degree views then test mostly expert terrain that Big Sky classifies as “triple black” — if you need to ask, you’re not good enough to ski it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Timmy Thomas, 77, Dies; Singer’s Big Hit Was an Antiwar Anthem
description: His “Why Can’t We Live Together” rose to the top of the Billboard charts in 1973. He could never match its success.
content: In the summer of 1972, the singer and keyboardist Timmy Thomas was watching the “CBS Evening News” and heard Walter Cronkite tick off the day’s death count of American and Vietcong soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Who Needs Ice? Roller-Skating Comes to Rockefeller Center.
description: A wheel-friendly rink is opening in Midtown’s famous sunken plaza, part of a rebrand of the Art Deco complex to attract more New Yorkers.
content: The winter ice-skating season may be drawing to a close at Rockefeller Center, but this year the party will continue after the ice thaws. Get ready for roller-skating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Future of Agency Created to Keep Mob Off Docks Now Up to Supreme Court
description: New Jersey wants to dissolve a product of the “On the Waterfront” era. New York wants the country’s highest court to keep the bistate commission alive.
content: A simmering feud over the future of an agency created 70 years ago to break organized crime’s grip on the cargo ports in and around New York City took an unusual turn on Monday when New York asked the U.S. Supreme Court to intervene.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sounds of Ukrainian Pop
description: A conversation about some of the country’s stars, the musical traditions they work within and how they have grappled with the war.
content: The Russian invasion of Ukraine is entering its fourth week, upending life, damaging cities and towns and spawning a refugee crisis. Culture, needless to say, has largely come to a standstill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Emily Cochrane
title: Biden to Withdraw Nomination for Fed’s Top Bank Cop
description: Sarah Bloom Raskin did not appear to have the votes for Senate confirmation as Fed vice chair for supervision after a key Democrat withheld his support.
content: President Biden will withdraw his nomination of Sarah Bloom Raskin to serve as the Federal Reserve’s top bank regulator on Tuesday, after a Democratic senator said he would join Republicans in voting against her, most likely dooming her chances of confirmation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Padgett
title: The Disaster That Is Venezuela
description: William Neuman’s “Things Are Never So Bad That They Can’t Get Worse” recounts the recent decline of Venezuela — and how that decline is continuing.
content: THINGS ARE NEVER SO BAD THAT THEY CAN’T GET WORSEInside the Collapse of VenezuelaBy William Neuman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Dan Bilefsky
title: Zelensky’s appeal to Canada: Imagine if Toronto were Kyiv.
description: The Ukrainian president’s emotional speech to Canadian lawmakers underscored how he has increasingly cast himself as a spokesman for liberal democracy.
content: OTTAWA — In an emotional address to Canada’s Parliament on Tuesday, President Volodymyr Zelensky urged its members to support his call for a no-fly zone over Ukraine, asking them to imagine cities like Vancouver or Toronto being attacked, and calling for intensifying sanctions in the face of Russian aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: In the War Over Ukraine, Expect the Unexpected
description: Wars bring out the best and the worst of humanity. Surprises are the only constant.
content: Every war brings surprises, but what is most striking about Vladimir Putin’s war against Ukraine — and indirectly against the whole democratic West — is how many of the bad surprises, so far, have been for Putin and how many of the good surprises have been for Ukraine and its allies around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Anushka Patil
title: At least nine House Democrats test positive for the coronavirus after a party retreat and late-night voting.
description: Three representatives reported positive tests on Tuesday morning. Several others tested positive after a party gathering last week in Philadelphia.
content: WASHINGTON — At least nine House Democrats have announced in the last five days that they tested positive for the coronavirus, with more than half of those cases emerging after lawmakers attended a party retreat last week in Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson, Alan Rappeport and Lauren Hirsch
title: Dollars or Rubles? Russian Debt Payments Are Due, and Uncertain.
description: Citing sanctions, the Russian government warned it might pay foreign debt obligations in rubles. Credit rating agencies say a default is imminent.
content: Russia is teetering on the edge of a possible sovereign debt default, and the first sign could come as soon as Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Latest Covid Surge
description: A new version of Omicron and Hong Kong’s rising death toll.
content: Even as Covid-19 cases and deaths have continued to decline in the United States, there are some worrisome developments around the world. Today, I’ll walk through them — and explain their implications for the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Music’s Messy Digital Revolution
description: Streaming services bring in steady cash for the music industry, but sales are down and many artists feel left out.
content: Streaming saved the music industry from the jaws of the internet. But the complicated picture from the past 20 years shows that surviving an online revolution isn’t the only hard part. What comes next might be even more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Heller
title: 50 Years Ago, James Brown Took an Unlikely Stage: Rikers Island
description: The story of how the Godfather of Soul ended up performing at the New York jail involves a dogged Board of Correction employee who knitted her way to the musician’s attention.
content: James Brown proudly called Augusta, Ga., his home. When it came to performing, the Apollo Theater on 125th Street in Harlem, where he recorded his 1963 breakthrough album “Live at the Apollo,” was his home away from home. But 50 years ago this week, he played at another New York City institution with a lot less fanfare.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Timothy Snyder
description: A conversation with historian Timothy Snyder.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Timothy Snyder. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and Jim Wilson
title: Oakland Cannabis Sellers, Once Full of Hope, Face a Harsh Reality
description: The cannabis industry, designed in part to help communities upended by the war on drugs, is being threatened by theft, racism and a market that is stacked against small operators.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Across from where the Athletics play baseball sits a two-story concrete building painted bright orange and white. It is home to a cannabis dispensary called Blunts and Moore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Yaqoob Akbary
title: Afghanistan’s Deadliest Highway Comes Back to Life
description: The once-perilous road from Kabul to Kandahar has changed under the Taliban.
content: The once-perilous road from Kabul to Kandahar has changed under the Taliban.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They Just Can’t Quit: Athletes Who Un-Retire
description: Many comebacks fizzle. Tom Brady’s remains to be seen. But here are a few of the most successful un-retirements in sports.
content: Many comebacks fizzle. Tom Brady’s remains to be seen. But here are a few of the most successful un-retirements in sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: About how many detectable earthquakes shake the Earth each year?
description: The Earth shakes a lot.
content: The Earth shakes a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Nordberg
title: The Case That Killed #MeToo in Sweden
description: It's the feminist capital of the world. So why isn't it letting women tell their stories?
content: It's the feminist capital of the world. So why isn't it letting women tell their stories?
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis and Jeremy Engle
title: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Ukraine War, 2020 Census, Pokémon
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Chodosh, Zach Levitt and Gus Wezerek
title: How to Think About the Ukrainian Refugee Crisis, in Maps and Charts
description: History shows that sympathy for refugees can be fleeting.
content: History shows that sympathy for refugees can be fleeting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Turn Toward American Cuisine
description: After building a small empire of Italian and French restaurants, Rita Sodi and Jody Williams are exploring the food of Shaker communities and other strands of American cookery.
content: After building a small empire of Italian and French restaurants, Rita Sodi and Jody Williams are exploring the food of Shaker communities and other strands of American cookery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At Home With Jerry Zaks
description: The Tony-winning director of ‘The Music Man’ pays more attention to the furnishings onstage than to those at home. But that suits him fine.
content: The Tony-winning director of ‘The Music Man’ pays more attention to the furnishings onstage than to those at home. But that suits him fine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Benjamin Foley and Axel Boada
title: Attack Hits Kyiv Neighborhood
description: An explosion rocked a residential neighborhood in Kyiv, killing one and injuring six. It was the second attack on a civilian area in the Ukrainian capital on Monday.
content: An explosion rocked a residential neighborhood in Kyiv, killing one and injuring six. It was the second attack on a civilian area in the Ukrainian capital on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Mark Boyer, Brent McDonald, Benjamin Foley and Andriana Zmysla
title: These Foreign Fighters Are Joining the Battle for Ukraine
description: Thousands of foreign volunteers — including Americans — are arriving in Ukraine to help defend the country. But an attack on their training camp on Sunday has left some wondering if they’ll ever see the front lines.
content: Thousands of foreign volunteers — including Americans — are arriving in Ukraine to help defend the country. But an attack on their training camp on Sunday has left some wondering if they’ll ever see the front lines.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Road Ahead for the Democrats: Here Are Some Directions
description: As the Democrats seek a sharper message, readers have some ideas. Also: The world must act in Ukraine; encourage parents.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
